title: Clovis Sleeping
transcript:
GLORIA GROOM: So this is a painting that shows his son Clovis beside a large wood tankard. And here he’s using it to set the mood along with this wallpaper, which has this sort of lyrical musical quality to it. It’s part of the dreamscape that he’s created for his young son. And he first shows it in a still life. He’s setting it up and he’s fascinated by the shape, by the way light’s catching it. And he’s setting up kind of a dialogue of sorts with this heavy wooden tankard and this smaller pewter pitcher. For he didn’t consider ordinary objects ordinary at all. For him they have a very special meaning. And he will continue to sort of fixate on objects, and figures, and motifs that inspire him and these will appear in his works throughout his career.

ALLISON PERELMEN: Walking further into the gallery you will see a large wooden cabinet. Here Gauguin is engaging with something he will do for the rest of his career: taking a found object and making it his own by carving into the surface, by adding decorative elements, painting them. Here, he is takes an elegant piece of furniture and deliberately makes it more crude with his rough carvings and mix of design elements. And although he’d likely did not construct this cabinet himself, he signed it “Gauguin Fecit”, which is Latin for “Gauguin made this,” to make clear that this wasn’t just a piece of furniture but an artwork in its own right.
